description: Erection of a single storey front/side extension, two storey side extension, part single storey/part two storey rear extension, rear dormer roof extension and installation of roof lights to facilitate loft conversion, plus erection of an ancillary outbuilding to rear
decision_conditions: The outbuilding hereby approved shall be used for purposes ancillary to the main dwelling house, and shall not be used, sold or sub-let as a separate self-contained unit. Reason: A separate unit of accommodation of this nature is not acceptable in this location in the interests of the amenities, character of the area and highway safety in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The roof of the single storey extension hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission. Reason: As required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The development hereby permitted shall be carried out in accordance with the materials specified on the approved plans and on the application form unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority. Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Before the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, any windows in the side (south-east) elevation and situated at first floor level and the window serving the shower room within the proposed outbuilding as shown on drawing number 79L-105-A shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable. Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

Application SiteThe site comprises of a semi-detached two-storey dwelling. The site does not comprise of a listed building, nor is it located within a conservation area or area of special character.ProposalThe application seeks planning permission for the erection of a two-storey rear extension with associated changes to fenestration. Planning History22/01419/HOU - Erection of two-storey rear extension with associated changes to fenestration. Rear dormer roof extension to facilitate loft conversion. Refused planning permission, dated 24 June, 2022.Reason for refusal: "By reason of scale, height, mass and design, the proposed two storey side and rear extension, would appear excessive in scale, dominant and would not relate well to the host dwelling, resulting in an incongruous appearance within the streetscene, thereby conflicting with Policies D3 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012."Consultation11no. properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.No statutory or internal consultations necessary.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact on the character and appearance of the area; - The impact on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers; - Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Policy Guidance 34 (Two-storey Rear Extensions) of the SPD Guidance is applicable to this application.The SPD guidance advises that a two storey rear extension may be considered acceptable, particularly in those instances where the dwelling occupies a spacious plot with substantial distances between boundaries and adjacent dwellings. Extensions proposed on a boundary of a semi-detached property are generally unacceptable and will normally be resisted. In this instance, the proposed rear extension would not be visible from the main street scene and its impact when viewed from the rear would be limited due to the large gardens and positioning of the property backing onto railway tracks. The proposed rear extension would add infill floorspace to the ground and first floor levels of the property to a depth of 3.9m and width of 1.6m, and would be set away from the adjoining semi-detached property at No. 64 by 3m as existing.The proposed rear extension would be constructed in facing bricks to match the host dwelling, which is acceptable. It is considered that the proposed development would preserve and maintain the character of the area and would not detract from the character and appearance of the host property or wider area, in accordance with Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LFD Core Strategy April 2012.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed two-storey rear extension is not considered to result in undue harm to either neighbouring property at No's 64 and 68 Dukes Avenue. The proposals also include a raised terrace area to the ground floor at the rear nearest to the boundary with No. 68, which is raised from the ground by 1.5m. Officers note that there is already a raised terrace of smaller area to the same height as proposed, and the proposals would merely extend around the rear elevation of the application property. As such, Officers do not consider that the proposals would lead to undue material loss of privacy to No. 68 than is currently the case. It is considered that the proposed development by virtue of its size, siting and design in relation to the neighbouring properties would not cause significant harm to the outlook, privacy and daylight/sunlight provision of the neighbouring occupiers and would therefore comply with Policy DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionThe proposal accords with the principles contained with policies DM10 in that it would relate well to the design of the existing dwellinghouse and would have no adverse impact on the character or quality of the character of the streetscene. In terms of neighbouring amenity, it is not considered to result in any undue harm in regards to overlooking, loss of privacy, daylight or outlook provision. The scheme is therefore considered to be acceptable and in accordance with the LDF Core Strategy Core Policies. Officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.

Consultations3no. surrounding properties were notified of the proposed development. No representations received.Planning HistoryNo planning history recorded.ProposalThe application seeks full planning permission for the conversion of garage into habitable space and erection of single storey rear extension.Site and SurroundingsThe application site comprises of a two-storey, detached dwellinghouse positioned at the end of Grapsome Close cul-de-sac.The surrounding properties comprise of predominantly detached and semi-detached two-storey dwellinghouses.The application site is not located within a Conservation Area and does not comprise of a statutory or locally listed building. Planning AssessmentThe key considerations in the assessment of this application are:-	Character and Appearance; -	The Impact upon Residential Amenity; -	The Impact upon Highways; and -	Fire SafetyCharacter and Appearance Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed single-storey rear extension would not be visible from the streetscene, contained to the rear. The proposals involve the erection of a single-storey rear extension to span the full width of the dwelling to a depth of 3m. The roof is shown to be of a pitch design with two velux windows. The extension would comply with Council's guidance on scale and design of single-storey rear extensions as outlined in Policy Guidance 33 of the Council's Residential Design SPD. The matching stock brick finish to the rear extension is considered acceptable, in keeping with the rear elevation of the host building. To the front elevation, the proposals seek to convert the integral garage into a habitable room with associated change from existing garage door to a window of a similar appearance to the existing main windows within the front elevation of the property. This is considered to be an acceptable alteration which would not result in any harm to the overall character and appearance of the host dwelling.Having regard to the above officers consider that there would be no material impact from the proposed development on the character and appearance of the area.Impact upon Residential AmenityPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 requires new development to deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity. Policy DM10 of the Kingston Core Strategy (2012) is clear that development proposals should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed rear single-storey extension would cause no significant increase in the loss of privacy, loss of daylight, sense of enclosure or loss of outlook to the adjoining properties. Officers note that there are no side-facing openings/glazing to the proposed rear extension towards either neighbouring property. The scale and design of the extension is such that it would comply with Council's guidance on such types of development. The alterations to the fenestration would not cause any materially harmful impacts to neighbouring amenity.Accordingly, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of residential amenity.Impact upon HighwaysPolicy DM10 of the Core Strategy states that proposals should have regard to local traffic conditions and highway safety and ensure that they are not adversely affected. The application involves the conversion of the integral garage space, although based on the existing floor plan, it does not appear to be of a size capable of fitting a modern car. Nevertheless, the area of hardstanding/driveway to the front of the property is of an adequate size to be used as a car parking space, and so the conversion would not result in the loss of a space that would impact upon highway safety.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development would accord with the relevant policies of the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), and Policies CS8, DM10 and DM12 of the Core Strategy (2012).The proposal by virtue of its scale, design and materiality is considered to be subservient to the host dwelling and would not result in harm to the character and appearance of the host dwelling or wider area. In addition, the proposals would not result in materially harmful impact to neighbouring amenity by way of overlooking, loss of light or sense of overbearing or enclosure. In addition adequate car parking space for the property would be retained, to the satisfaction of the Council.Recommendation:That planning permission be GRANTED

In addition, the proposals would not result in materially harmful impact to neighbouring amenity by way of overlooking, loss of light or sense of overbearing or enclosure. Recommendation:That planning permission be GRANTED

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.9x neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Fire Safety.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: Planning permission was granted at no.16 Sandhurst Avenue for adding a pitched roof to an existing porch and garage in April 2017 (Planning ref. 17/16101/HOU).  As such, officers consider that that the proposed development would appear an appropriate addition to the host property. Further, officers note that the form and siting of the proposed development would be consistent with the prevailing pattern of development in the immediate streetscene, and as such the proposed development would not appear out of keeping with the surrounding area. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the siting of the proposed development, it would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy. However, officers feel that for the size of the development sought, securing further details by means of a planning condition, would be unnecessary.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
